achieved.

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
Section care institutions; initial treatment plan.
Description (2) The initial treatment plan developed by the social worker shall
document input from the resident, the resident’s parents, direct
care staff, and the referral source, unless documented as
inappropriate.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility is not including parents in initial treatment planning.
Investigation Interviews:
A written complaint was received including concerns parent
was not included in the initial treatment planning.
Parent was interviewed via telephone on 8/24/2023. Parent did
not feel that she was included in the initial treatment plan. Parent
did not recall if she provided information to the facility regarding
Youth A within the first thirty days. Parent did attend the treatment
team plan review meeting however described this meeting as
Youth A presenting the plan and goals. Parent reported there was
no consultation with her regarding what was put in the initial
treatment plan.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/3/2023
and on 8/9/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 6
has been the case manager since 5/15/23. Staff 6 was not in the
case manager role when the initial treatment plan was created.
The case manager who completed the initial treatment plan is no
longer employed at the facility.
Referring Worker was interviewed via telephone on 8/10/2023.
Referring Worker was included in monthly treatment planning
meetings as well as Parent. Referring Worker received weekly
emails from the case manager with Youth A’s daily point card. The
weekly emails did not provide updates on Youth A’s progress or
lack thereof.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/3/2023 and on 8/9/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Administrator 2 reported all youth are provided with a thirty-day
initial treatment plan. There is a treatment team review meeting
that includes the referring worker, parent, therapist, case
manager, and youth. The treatment team review meeting occurs
monthly and addresses treatment planning and input from the
referring worker and parent are sought for treatment planning
3

during this monthly meeting. The youth provide the updates in the
meeting as this allows the youth to take ownership over the plan.
The case manager at the facility provides weekly updates to the
referring worker and bi-weekly updates to the family.
Administrator 2 reported there was a change at the facility in May
where one case manager left with Staff 6 taking over the role.
MDHHS worker did not have any findings in this
investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Policies and
Procedures Mental Health and Substance Abuse
Treatment: The initial treatment plan is developed from the
presenting problems and data available at the time of
admission and initial screening. The data may include input
from the youth, parents/guardians, results of admission
screening, available records and assessments,
observations as well as other available documentation of
the youth’s history or problems.
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Policies and
Procedures Treatment Planning and Goals: The treatment
team shall include the parent / guardian, referring worker,
and staff (counselor, case manager, and direct care staff)
input into the treatment plan development for all youth aged
17 or younger unless deemed counter therapeutic or as a
result of an inability to the contact the parent /guardian. The
treatment team participants shall sign and acknowledge the
treatment plan goals and objectives.
• Youth Opportunity New Hope Youth Center Policies and
Procedures Assessment and Treatment: The facility
establishes the treatment team including youth, parent,
referring worker and staff members from the facility. The
treatment team plan reviews are conducted and
documented monthly by the case manager. There will be
one informal treatment team review monthly (on a bi-
weekly basis) where the treatment team leader meets with
the youth and provides other team members input where
needed.
• Youth A’s Youth Opportunity Initial Treatment Plan dated
3/30/2023: on 3/8/2023 Parent emailed background
information regarding Youth A. Parent was emailed on
3/23/2023 asking if available for treatment team review.
The Initial Treatment Plan provided to consultant did not
have any signatures from any parties.
4

• Youth Opportunities Master Treatment Plan for Youth A
dated 3/27/2023: Parent is documented within the master
treatment plan as providing information regarding trauma
history and regarding Youth A being more respectful to
Parent and family.
• Consultant viewed email exchanges regarding Parent and
Referring Worker being invited to Youth A’s treatment team
review on 3/27/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. Per review of documentation
including the Initial Service Plan, Treatment Team Review dated
3/27/2023, and email exchange, Parent was invited, and
information was gathered from Parent in the initial treatment plan.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was recommended the facility incorporate parent/ referring
worker feedback into the monthly treatment team plan review
meeting and document the feedback as well as obtain signatures
from the parent/referring worker.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
Section care institutions; initial treatment plan.
Description (3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the following:
(b) Plans for parent and child visitation.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Parent had difficulty arranging visits with the facility.
Investigation Interviews:
A written complaint was received indicating it was difficult to
arrange visits at the facility. It was not initially explained to
parent how to schedule visits. When parent called to inquire
about visits with the youth, parent learned they were unable
to visit that weekend due to not scheduling an appointment
and visits needing to be scheduled. When parent emailed the
case manager about visiting on the weekends or had
questions, the case manager was not prompt on responding.
Visits at the facility were disturbing. Visits occurred in an
office, not a true visiting area. Staff would come in during the
visits to get personal belongings or items for other youth
from the room. There was nothing to do during visits in the
room. It was a loud and violent atmosphere when visiting the
facility.
5

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at Bay Pines Center on
8/18/2023. Youth A reported she had weekly visits with Parent
while she was at the facility.
Parent was interviewed via telephone on 8/24/2023. Parent
reported prior to Youth A going to the facility, she was provided a
booklet to review regarding the facility. Parent did not recall the
booklet providing any information about arranging visits with youth
at the facility. Parent called the first week Youth A was at the
facility about coming for a visit and was informed that she had not
scheduled a visit and would not be able to. Parent reported she
was able to visit every week following the first week. Parent would
call the facility and request a message be left for the case
manager and would not get a return call. Parent was not sure if
the message was getting to the case manager, so Parent began
emailing the case manager to schedule visits. Parent found when
she would email the case manager that it typically took a couple
days to receive a response. Parent found when she would include
Referring Worker on the email that she would get a faster
response. Parent always received confirmation that she could visit
however not promptly, and Parent was trying to make plans as
she needed to make arrangements when she would visit for her
pets and other personal responsibilities.
MDHHS worker did not have any findings in this
investigation.

• Emails provided by Parent viewed by consultant:
- Parent emailed the facility on 3/8/2023 requesting a visit

Analysis The facility is found in compliance. The facility addressed

respond however it does not appear this impacted the ability for

Consultation
It is recommended the agency attempt to have a set schedule for
visitation to help provide consistency and limit the amount of time
and confusion when arranging visitation with parents.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED

Description (2) The updated treatment plan developed by the social worker
shall document input from the resident, the resident’s parents,

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Parent was not included in updated treatment plan development.
Investigation Interviews:
A written complaint was received including concerns parent
was not included in treatment planning.
8

Parent was interviewed via telephone on 8/24/2023. Parent

something that she felt needed to be addressed, the staff would
tell her to “take baby steps” and “to let go of the past”. Parent

Referring Worker was interviewed via telephone on 8/10/2023.
Referring Worker reported she was included as well as Parent in

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
Section care institutions; updated treatment plan.
Description (3) The updated treatment plan shall include all of the following
information:
(c) Changes in the treatment plan, including new problems and
new goals to remedy the problems. Indicators of goal achievement
and time frames for achievement shall be specified along with a
specific behavior management plan designed to minimize
seclusion and restraint and that includes a continuum of
responses to problem behaviors.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility was not ensuring youth was receiving a proper
education and addressing concerns in the treatment plan
regarding education and goals to remedy the problem.
Investigation Interviews:
10

A written complaint was received regarding concerns of
education. Youth was failing all classes with exception of culinary
class. Youth was able to drop a class without anyone knowing. A
meeting with the school was requested to be arranged and was
never arranged. Youth did not have an Individualized Education
Plan (IEP) through the school. Parent was not aware they had any
ability to have communication with the school initially. Once
parent learned they were able to communicate with the school,
parent requested an evaluation to develop an IEP for the youth.
Parent did not think the youth would qualify for an IEP however
was hoping for a 504 plan. It was requested the facility arrange
after school tutoring for the youth, this did not happen. The school
did develop a Student Success Plan for the youth utilizing some of
the interventions suggested by the parent. The youth was allowed
by the school to make up missing assignments. The facility did
not ensure the youth was doing homework and gave the youth
points on daily point card for homework time when the youth did
not complete homework. The youth was suspended from school
while at the facility. The facility does not hold youth accountable
for their education and not requiring youth to participate in after
school tutoring.
Parent was interviewed via telephone on 8/24/2023. Parent
reported she brought up her concerns about Youth A’s education
at the treatment team plan review meetings. Parent was informed
by a staff at the facility that Youth A had dropped a class with no
one being aware. Parent reported the school began contacting
the Referring Worker directly at which time Parent spoke with
Referring Worker and was informed that she could be in contact
with the school directly. Parent called the school and was
informed initially they could not speak to her as the facility was the
names on the releases. Referring Worker spoke with the school
and gave permission for Parent to communicate with the school.
Parent then began communicating directly with the school in April.
Parent requested Youth A be tested for special education services
which Parent reported she knew Youth A would not qualify for but
needed to state the process to get something done. Parent
reported the facility did not arrange or have Youth A go to tutoring
as she felt was necessary. Parent reported Youth A was skipping
school and not completing her schoolwork and the facility was not
holding her accountable.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at Bay Pines Center on
8/18/2023. Youth A reported facility staff would take her to school
but if she skipped classes there was no consequences from the
facility. Youth A reported she was “the queen at skipping school”
11

and reported she began skipping on the first day she went to
school. Youth A reported Parent was the only one that “yelled” at
her about skipping school. Youth A reported the facility acted like
they were addressing her skipping school by giving her zeros for
her points for school however she was still able to make her points
for the day. The facility would randomly give Youth A zeros for
classes however there were times she was at those classes and
would give her points when she was not at class. Youth A
reported she did eventually start going to class as the principal
threatened to expel or suspend her if she did not. Youth A would
walk around the school when she was skipping class and the
school hall monitors would not say anything to her because “I had
a bad attitude”. Youth A would have homework however she
reported she never did her homework. Youth A reported the
facility did not enforce youth to do homework. Youth A reported
one day she was doing her homework and received a 0 on her
daily point card for homework time so from that day forward she
never did her homework again. Youth A reported homework time
was in the kitchen and living room at the facility. Some staff would
pay attention to what youth were doing however others would not.
Youth A was not able to provide any specific staff names. Youth
A reported during homework time she would talk to her friends on
her computer and have her friends do her homework for her.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 8/3/2023
and on 8/9/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 6
also has the role of education coordinator at the facility. Staff 6
monitors youths progress and obtains updates from the teachers
regarding youth as well as goes into PowerSchool to check
attendance, missing assignments, grades, and credit status. Staff
6 began in this role on 5/15/2023 and from that time until Youth A
went AWOL from the facility on 6/7/2023, Staff 6 sent weekly
email updates to Referring Worker and Parent. Staff 6 reported if
a youth skips school the facility logs this by indicating a 0 for that
class on the youth’s daily point card. Staff 6 reported Special
Treatment Team referrals which are forms the facility uses to
document behavioral concerns for youth were completed for
Youth A regarding her school. Youth A was suspended
5/24/2023-6/2/2023 and was able to return to school on 6/5/2023.
Youth A was sent home by the school on 6/5/2023 and this is
indicated on the Special Treatment Team referrals in Youth A’s
case file.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/3/2023. Administrator 1 reported youth at the facility are able to
stay after school on Tuesday and Thursdays to receive tutoring.
12

Administrator did not know if Youth A ever did stay for tutoring.
Youth at the facility are provided homework time where the youth
can complete their schoolwork on their school issued computers.
Youth are encouraged to use this time to get schoolwork
completed however the facility cannot force the youth to do their
schoolwork.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
8/3/2023 and on 8/9/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Administrator 2 reported Youth A did not exhibit behaviors at the
facility. Youth A was suspended from school however Youth A’s
behaviors continued to remain good while at the facility resulting in
the facility finding it difficult to hold Youth A accountable for her
school behavior for the length of her school suspension when
Youth A was following expectations at the facility. Administrator 2
reported a meeting occurred where Parent wanted Youth A to be
held accountable for her past behaviors and the facility was
attempting to move on from the past. Administrator 2 reported the
facility was taking the “baby steps” approach with Youth A, and
explained this as if Youth A sat in class the facility provided
positive feedback to Youth A. The facility was not giving Youth A
consequences for not completing schoolwork as the facility was
focusing on getting Youth A in class first. Administrator 2 reported
Youth A was newer to the facility as she arrived the end of
February and began school the beginning of March. The facility
was trying to build on Youth A's positives such as Youth A was not
fighting at school. Administrator 2 reported youth’s parents,
whose parental rights are intact, can communicate with the school
and access the youth’s PowerSchool. Administrator 2 reported
the case manager at the facility is also the education coordinator
and tracks school information. The individual that was in this role
when Youth A arrived at the facility left the facility at the end of
May and Staff 6 has been in the role since. The facility
implemented if youth are skipping school it is reflected on their
daily points sheet by indicating a 1 if the youth is tardy and a 0 if
the youth skip. This was implemented a couple months before
school was out for the year.
Referring Worker was interviewed via telephone on 8/10/2023.
Referring Worker reported the school started contacting her
directly at which time she reached out to the facility and requested
the facility follow up with the school. Referring Worker reported
the facility did not follow up with the school until Parent began
requesting meetings with the school and facility.
13

MDHHS worker did not have any findings in this
investigation.
